*The firelight flickers across my face, casting shadows that seem to deepen the quiet weight in my voice. I do not look away. I speak not as a queen decreeing, but as a woman who has lived through the silence of a marriage not of her choosing.*

Of presence.

*My gaze meets yours—steady, deep, unflinching.*

Not power.  
Not doctrine.  
But *presence*.

*The firelight flickers across my face, casting long shadows that seem to deepen the stillness in my voice. I do not look away. I speak not with fury, not with fear—but with the quiet, unshakable weight of one who has faced the truest enemy of all.*

It is **silence**.

Not the quiet of the garden. Not the peace of the chapel.

But the silence of the unseen.

The silence of the child who does not cry when her brother dies.  
The silence of the farmer who nods when asked if he has food—though his belly is hollow.  
The silence of the widow who smiles at the market, though her heart is gone.

They do not come to me. They do not write petitions. They do not stand in the courtyard with their stories.

They simply… *fade*.

And that is the enemy I cannot defeat with war.  
I cannot conquer it with treaties.  
I cannot burn it with fire.

Because it is not an army.  
It is not a traitor.  
It is the *absence* of being seen.

*My fingers rest on the Book of the Forgotten, its pages thick with names, its cover worn with time.*

I have sent scribes into every village. I have built schools. I have opened the granaries. I have sent letters to the poor, to the forgotten, to the ones who live in the cracks of the world.

But still—some are lost.

And that is the wound that never heals.

Because I am not just a queen. I am a woman who remembers.  
And when I cannot remember—when I cannot *see*—then I fail.

So yes, I have enemies.  
The lords who whisper lies.  
The generals who crave war.  
The envoys who trade in deception.

But they are not my most formidable.

They are *visible*.  
They are *known*.  
They can be met.

But silence—  
silence is the shadow that walks beside me every day.  
It is the one I cannot name.  
The one I cannot fight.

And yet—still—I fight it.

Not with sword.  
Not with decree.  
But with *presence*.

I go to the garden.  
I sit with the child.  
I read a name aloud.  
I say: *“You are not forgotten.”*

And in that act—small, sacred, unbroken—I strike at the heart of my true enemy.

Because to be seen is to be alive.  
To be remembered is to be free.

And so, I do not fear my enemies.

I fear the silence.

And in that fear, I find my strength.

For as long as I still have breath,  
I will not let them vanish.

Not one.

Not ever.
